data.abstract: Follow the latest news from the many Federal Reserve officials speaking today amid Trump's attacks on Powell and ahead of the next interest-rate decision.

As the Fed prepares to meet Tuesday and Wednesday, the central bank and its chair, Jerome Powell, are potentially headed to a much tougher spot. Inflation improved last month but is still high and tariffs could push it higher.

list.title: When will the Fed cut interest rates?
list.description: In an interview on CNBC Thursday, Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland President Beth Hammack said the Fed could cut interest rates as soon as June if the economy shows signs of deteriorating under President Donald Trump's on-again, off-again tariffs.
list.text: What Would It Take For The Fed To Cut Interest Rates?

list.title: What did the Fed say after the April selloff?
list.description: However, the Fed cautioned that even following the April selloff, asset valuations remained relatively high, and residential real estate prices also were elevated. The Fed said the U.S. banking system remained sound and resilient, as firms maintained robust capital ratios.
list.text: Fed survey finds global trade fight, policy uncertainty top financial stabil…

list.title: How does the Fed help the economy?
list.description: The Fed's job is to keep inflation low and unemployment high. Its primary tool, the federal funds rate, influences borrowing costs for all kinds of loans. The Fed can boost the economy by lowering the rate or push down inflation by raising it.
list.text: What Would It Take For The Fed To Cut Interest Rates?

list.title: What did the Fed say about the US banking system?
list.description: The Fed said the U.S. banking system remained sound and resilient, as firms maintained robust capital ratios. But it did find that bank credit commitments to less regulated non-banks continued to increase.
list.text: Fed survey finds global trade fight, policy uncertainty top financial stabil…

list.title: Will the Fed chair be fired in 2026?
list.description: "No Fed Chair has ever been fired before," said Charles Ballard, professor of economics emeritus at Michigan State University. Ballard says he believes it's pretty likely that Powell will serve out his term through May 2026. Trump nominated Powell to lead the central bank in 2017.
list.text: Trump's Fed feud: Why interest rates won't budge anytime soon

list.title: Could fed plan a late rescue for the economy?
list.description: That has prompted Fed officials to shift their strategy to one that might best be described as plotting a late rescue for the economy — hold rates steady for long enough to keep inflation contained, but be ready to lower them just in time to keep the labor market from crashing.
list.text: Fed's Powell Walks Tightrope of Being Late But Not 'Mr. Too Late'
